Biochemical Analysis, College of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering, Qingdao University of Science and Technology, Qingdao 266042, Shandong, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. The green production of hydrogen from electrocatalytic water splitting is an important base and promising direction for the future of the large-scale application of hydrogen energy. The key of green hydrogen evolution depends on the development of low-cost and highly active electrocatalysts. Molybdenum carbides (Mo x C), as a typical of earth-abundant transition-metal material, have accumulated great attention due to their low cost, earth abundance, electrical conductivity, similar d-band state to Pt, and regulated morphology/electronic structures. In this paper, recent researches focusing on Mo x C for efficient HER in a wide pH range are summarized from respects of modulation of unique morphology, electronic structure, and electrode interface step by step. Briefly, modulation of morphology influence the apparent activity of catalyst, modulation of electronic structure of active sites by heteroatom doping and designing heterointerface boost intrinsic HER kinetics, and modulation of electrode interface via hybridization of MoxC structures with carbon materials can ensure the fast electron transfer and boost the activity. Besides the above methods discussed, perspective and challenges of designing Mo x C as the substitute of Pt-based electrocatalyst for practical hydrogen generation in a wide pH range are pointed out. Graphical abstract This review focuses on summarizing Mo x C from respects of modulation of its nanostructures, electronic structure by heteroatom doping and designing heterointerface, and electrode interface as efficient HER electrocatalyst in a wide pH range. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Molybdenum carbides Classification Electrocatalyst Modulation strategy Hydrogen evolution 1 Introduction Reducing fossil fuel dependence and the carbon footprint by exploring new forms of energy and energy carriers is a pressing need in the long term [1–3]. Molecular hydrogen has shown its potential as an ideal energy carrier due to the carbon-free and its high energy density [4–6]. Hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) via water electrocatalysis from renewable and clean energy (e.g. solar, wind, tidal) is one of the cleanest and most sustainable methods for large-scale hydrogen production [7–9]. At the heart of these efforts, the biggest challenge lies in designing and synthesizing efficient electrocatalysts for the reactions included in water splitting [10–12]. Generally, Pt and its alloys have proven to be the most active electrocatalysts for HER, but the low abundance and high cost restrict their large-scale application [13–15]. Therefore, development of cost-effective electrocatalysts based on earth abundant elements with high HER activity as Pt substitutes are highly desired. Among various candidates, group VI transition-metal carbides (TMCs) have been widely reported as HER catalysts in view of their similar d-band electronic structures, optimal hydrogen-adsorption energy, and catalytic properties to Pt-based metals [16,17]. Molybdenum carbides (Mo x C), including Mo2C or MoC, as an important member of TMCs, have aroused great interest as efficient HER electrocatalysts since 2012 due to their low cost, earth abundance, good electrical conductivity, similar d-band state to Pt, and regulated morphology/electronic structures [18–24]. In addition, Mo x C structures exhibit excellent HER activity and stability in a wide pH range. Considering the much lower activity of Pt-based materials in alkaline media than in acidic solution, to adapt to various harsh conditions, development of cost-effective Mo x C structures to replace noble metal Pt-based materials is feasible and sustainable for large-scale hydrogen production. Given that HER is a gas-involving electrochemical reaction and pristine Mo x C binding with H intermediate is so strong, structural, electronic, and interfacial modulation of Mo x C catalysts step by step at the nanoscale has been pursued to fulfill the high demand of efficient catalysis [25]. Designing unique Mo x C structures with large surface and more exposed active sites influence the apparent activity of electrocatalyst [26,27]. Heteroatom doping and designing heterointerface of Mo x C structures to optimize the electronic structure boost intrinsic HER kinetics [28–31]. Modulation of electrode interface via hybridization of Mo x C structures with carbon materials can ensure the electron transfer and boost the activity [32–34]. Meanwhile, some progresses are made on the structure-activity relationship to provide direction for further development of Mo x C catalysts [35,36]. So this pivotal work focuses on a variety of studies applying Mo x C as efficient catalysts for HER in a wide pH range, especially in acidic and alkaline media. These principles to modulate electrocatalyst for enhanced HER activity have opened up a new pathway in designing non-noble metal catalysts for HER. Here, we focus our discussions on the recent progress in the design of Mo x C-based electrocatalysts and the modulation strategies to maximize the electrocatalytic HER activity. This review firstly has a brief introduction of HER and Mo x C, and followed by detailed discussion of modulation strategies to reveal structure-activity relationship, which include the modulation of unique morphology, electronic structure and electrode interface. The apparent activity of the Mo x C structures are impacted by its morphology, because the active species are expected to have full exposure, heteroatom doping and designing heterointerface are revealed to be an efficient strategy for altering the electronic structure of Mo x C structures, thereby generating intrinsically improved activity, the hybridization of Mo x C structures with carbon materials could realize the uniform dispersion of Mo x C nanoparticles and strongly coupled interface, thus accelerating the electron transfer and improving the intrinsic activity. Finally, some key challenges and issues which should not be ignored for designing Mo x C composites for practical hydrogen generation are pointed out. These issues are instructive for the future development of Mo x C composites or other non-noble metal-based HER electrocatalysts. 2 Fundamentals of electrochemical HER and molybdenum carbides HER, as the half reaction of water splitting, is a two-step process occurring on the surface of cathode in both acidic and alkaline media, and the corresponding Tafel slopes derived from Butler-Volmer equation are usually used to distinguish the possible HER mechanism (Eqs. (1)–(6)) [1,37,38]. The first step for HER is the Volmer reaction with the Tafel slope of 120 mV dec−1, in which a proton reacts with an electron to generate an adsorbed hydrogen atom (Hads) (Eqs. (1) and (4)) [39,40]. According to the reaction media with different pH for water splitting, the proton source in acidic and alkaline electrolytes are the hydronium cation (H3O+) and the water molecule, respectively. After generation of Hads, the H2 formation can proceed via the ion and atom reaction (Heyrovsky step, Eqs. (2) and (5)) or the atom combination reaction (Tafel step, Eqs. (3) and (6)) with the Tafel slopes of 40 and 30 mV dec−1, respectively [39,41]. Generally, the practical HER usually derive Tafel slopes among three standard values due to the fact that HER proceeds via the combined two reaction steps, i.e., Volmer-Heyrovsky or Volmer-Tafel and a lower Tafel slope is beneficial for HER as the much smaller overpotential can drive a larger current density. (1) H3O+ + e −→ Hads + H2O (2) Hads + H3O+ + e − → H2 + H2O (3) Hads + Hads → H2 (4) H2O + e −→ Hads + OH− (5) Hads + H2O + e − → H2 + OH− (6) Hads + Hads → H2 The exchange current density (j 0) is also an important parameter to interpret the intrinsic electrocatalytic activity of catalyst under equilibrium conditions [42,43]. The j 0 value influences the rate of the HER at other potentials. The Tafel equation is usually used to interpret the relationship of current density (j) and overpotential (η) (Eq. (7)): (7) η = blog(j/j 0) where j 0 is obtained at zero overpotential and b represents the Tafel slope. A catalyst having a higher j 0 and a smaller b is highly desirable. As is mentioned above, Hads is always involved in the HER regardless of the reaction steps. Therefore, the Gibbs free energy for hydrogen adsorption (ΔG H*) has been considered as a good descriptor of the intrinsic activity of materials for HER. Norskov et al. has reported a plot of j 0 against ΔG H* with a volcano shape [44]. If ΔG H* is negative largely, the catalysts bind hydrogen atoms too strongly, making the Volmer reaction easily and failing to evolve hydrogen. If ΔG H* is positive largely, the catalysts bind hydrogen atoms too weakly, resulting in a slow Volmer reaction and prohibiting the HER reaction from occurring [45]. Therefore, the hydrogen binding energy should be moderate for an ideal catalyst to realize the optimal HER catalytic activity. Pt and its alloys as the benchmarking catalysts for HER located at the summit of the volcano possess the nearly zero ΔG H*, but they are seriously limited by their high cost and scarcity [46,47]. Molybdenum carbides (Mo x C), as a typical compound of transition-metal carbides (TMCs), have been widely applied as efficient catalysts for hydrodesulfurization (HDS) [48], hydrodenitrogenization (HDN) [49], isomerization [50,51], Water-Gas-Shift (WGS) [52], and Fischer-Tropsch synthesis [53], etc. Density functional theoretical (DFT) calculation of Mo x C revealed that the hybridization between Mo d-orbitals and C sp-orbitals broadened the d-band of Mo x C, closely resembling with that of Pt (Fig. 1 (a)) [54]. Therefore, the similar d-band of Mo x C to Pt makes it as promising alternatives to noble-metal Pt-based catalysts for HER. Initially, pristine Mo2C served as a good support for Pt in HER and its HER activity was not investigated in detail [55]. Hu et al. firstly reported that commercial β-Mo2C exhibited surprisingly high activity and durability for HER in both acidic and alkaline media [18]. However, the HER activity of Mo2C particles is inferior to Pt catalyst, there still exists tremendous potential to further improve the HER performance. Hu's group was concentrated on only one Fe2N structured β-Mo2C, while Leonard et al. reported four phases of Mo x C (α-MoC1- x , β-Mo2C, η-MoC, and γ-MoC) with different stacking sequence, and compared their catalytic activities for HER in acidic media (Fig. 1(b)). The results revealed that the catalytic activities of the four phases towards HER increased in the order of α-MoC1- x < η-MoC < γ-MoC < β-Mo2C and γ-MoC was the most stable catalysts in acidic media (Fig. 1(c)) [56,57]. Usually the Mo x C with different crystal phases induce the different electronic structures due to the different interactions between Mo and C, thus leading to the shift of d-band center (ɛ d) [23,58]. The hydrogen binding energy on metals decreases with the ε d downshifting away from the Fermi level (E F) [59–61]. According to the reported literature, the calculated ɛ d were −3.02, −3.18, and −4.79 eV for β-Mo2C, α-MoC, and δ-MoC, respectively, and the calculations revealed that β-Mo2C exhibited a stronger metallic character, whereas α-MoC and δ-MoC with large ionic contribution exhibited the strongest covalent character. A low work function of 3.4 eV on β-Mo2C (011) indicated that it could be applied for (electro)catalytic processes because the electron transfer between surface and adsorbate is essential [62]. Therefore, the regulation of the ε d by controlling the phase of TMCs is possible to optimize the hydrogen binding energy, thus enhancing the HER kinetics and activities. Besides tuning the phases of Mo x C, metallic or nonmetallic doping are demonstrated the most effective method to alter the electronic configuration and boost the HER activities [25,63]. Additionally, modulation of nano/microstructures of Mo x C to fully exposure and utilize the active sites can significantly impact the HER activities. Furthermore, the hybridization of Mo x C with carbon materials can realize the uniform dispersion of active sites and strongly coupled interface, thus promoting the electron transfer and boosting the HER activities. 3 Modulation of nanostructures of molybdenum carbides 3.1 Organic-inorganic hybrid derivation Traditional temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) of the molybdenum oxides by gaseous hydrocarbons (CH4/H2, C2H6/H2, C3H8/H2, C4H10/H2, etc.) are widely employed to prepare Mo x C composites [64–68]. However, this method for preparing Mo x C are influenced by the gas components, temperature ramping rate, and flow rate, which will result in the uncontrollable compositions, crystal phases and nano/microstructures of the Mo x C catalysts. And the generation of Mo x C by employing carbon-rich flammable gasses at high temperature is dangerous and environmentally unfriendly. Additionally, incomplete transformation due to the gas-solid interface reaction and polymeric carbon species covering derived from pyrolysis of excessive gaseous hydrocarbons are unavoidable, which will result in the unstable gas-solid interface and poor HER activity [48,69,70]. Some other methods including chemical vapor deposition (CVD), sonochemical, and annealing mechanochemical synthesis methods are also developed to prepare Mo x C structures [71–73]. However, the rigid manipulation process is complex and the inevitable carbon deposition would block the active sites and poison the Mo x C surface. Therefore, searching for facile and safe preparations with precise modulation is highly desirable to realize the large-scale production of Mo x C composites. Recently, a new route using organic-inorganic hybrids as precursors for chemical transformation towards the synthesis of Mo x C electrocatalysts has been widely adopted [74–76]. The inorganic Mo-O crosslink with organic H+-N through hydrogen bonds, then the polymerization reaction takes place to form organic-inorganic hybrids. Specifically, the inorganic framework and organic molecules with nano or atom-scale dimension serve as self-assembly templates and sacrificial agents, respectively, making the Mo x C electrocatalysts with modulated nano/microstructures, band gaps, electronic structure, defects, etc. [24,77,78]. In sharp contrast to conventional transformation strategy with many difficulties in simultaneously realizing multiple structural parameters, the organic-inorganic hybrids strategy into Mo x C electrocatalysts involves the partial removal of organic components and the reconstruction of inorganic components simultaneously [79]. Furthermore, this strategy integrates the merits of facile and safe operation without using flammable gas flow (H2, CH4, C2H6, etc.) and homogeneous and complete transformation into Mo x C electrocatalysts with easily modulated surface and well-defined nanostructures [48,80]. A representative strategy to prepare nanoporous Mo2C nanowires (np-Mo2C NWs) was to pyrolyze MoO x /amine hybrid precursors with sub-nanometer contact between amine molecules and molybdenum oxides under an inert atmosphere [81]. As shown in Fig. 2 (a) and (b), the uniform 1D morphology of np-Mo2C NWs being several micrometers long and 80–150 nm wide derived from the MoO x /amine hybrid precursors were obtained, which mainly ascribed to the anisotropic MoO4 2− leaded to the 1D growth of Mo2C composites [82]. Such organic-inorganic hybrids nanowires composed of ultrafine nanocrystallites with the size of ~10–15 nm can not only expose more active surface but also promote fast ions and electrons transfer, thus boosting the activity (Fig. 2(c)). Also, the nanostructures of MoO x /amine can easily be tuned from 1D to 3D nanostructures due to the anisotropy of MoO4 2− clusters, affording MoxC with modulated morphology [82]. As is mentioned above, catalytic HER activities of the Mo x C catalyst are closely related to crystalline phases, so further modulation of the crystalline phases of Mo x C catalysts to optimize the electron structure is highly desirable to boost HER activities. As is shown in Fig. 2(d)–(f), Gao and Tang et al. further prepared MoC-Mo2C heteronanowires, which were composed of α-Mo2C and η-MoC ultrafine nanoparticles via facile controlled carbonization [83]. Another effective strategy to modulate the electron structures is element doping, so they synthesized Co-doped Mo2C 1D nanowires composed of nanoparticles with the size ~10–15 nm based on Co-modified MoO x /amine precursor (Fig. 2(g)–(i)) [84]. Besides 1D nanowires structures, various morphologies of Mo x C varying from 1D to 3D structures with different phases have been modulated using amine as guest molecules via facile controlled reaction parameters [82]. Other organic guest molecules such as pyrrole, dopamine, and p-phenylenediamine are also employed to prepare Mo x C materials with various morphologies [28,85,86]. Recently, considering the large-scale application, core-shell structured Mo2C encapsulated by ultrathin carbon layers have been well designed to maintain its long-term durability [87,88]. Hu's group designed unique Mo2C@C nanospheres with pomegranate-like morphology by using phosphomolybdic acid as the oxidant to stimulate the polymerization reaction of pyrrole monomer, as illustrated in Fig. 3 (a) [28]. Fig. 3(b)-(d) revealed that a number of well-crystallized hexagonal Mo2C with the size of ~8.5 nm were encapsulated in a several layers of carbon. This strategy relies on existence of phosphomolybdic acid at the molecular scale interconnected with the polymer network that promotes the formation of core-shell structured Mo2C@C nanospheres. Contrary to just employing one kind of organic, our group synthesized core-shell structured N-doped Mo2C encapsulated by carbon nanospheres by using MoO4 2−/aniline-pyrrole as precursor, in which aniline and pyrrole were both employed as organics to interconnect with inorganic MoO4 2− [85]. Fig. 3(e)–(g) exhibited that Mo2C@NC nanospheres composed of a large number of ultrafine Mo2C nanocrystallites were uniformly encapsulated by ultrathin carbon layers. Recently, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs)-assisted strategy has been well developed to fabricate Mo x C nanomaterials due to the periodically porous structure, heteroatoms-containing organic ligands, and Mo clusters interconnected with ligands in atomic scale [89–92]. Li et al. synthesized the Mo2C@porous carbon (Mo2C@PC) by depositing highly dispersive MoO2 nanoparticles in porous carbon via utilizing MOFs to capture the vaporized MoO3 and subsequent carbonization process [93]. Lou's group also developed a Cu-based MOFs-assisted strategy for synthesizing porous MoC x nano-octahedrons consisted of many small η-MoC nanocrystallites embedded in carbon matrix by introducing guest polyoxometalates into the Cu-based MOFs host. MOFs-assisted strategy is also applicable for designing element-doped Mo x C nanostructures to further enhance the intrinsic activity of Mo x C composites. Ni-decorated MoC x hollow nanospheres derived from a polyoxometalate-incorporated MOF precursors have been designed and synthesized, as shown in Fig. 4 (a) [29]. Fig. 4(b) and (c) revealed that the Ni-decorated MoC x exhibited nanospherical-like morphology with a lot of small nanoparticles uniformly decorated throughout every hollow nanosphere. The unique precursor composed of outer layer of the carbon-containing polymer could enable the confined carbonization reaction and prevent MoC x and Ni from coalescence and detachment effectively. As expected, the MoC x obtained at 800 °C exhibited remarkable HER activity, which only needed an overpotential of 123 mV at 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 4(d)). As an evolution of MOFs, zeolite-imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) are also employed to prepare Mo x C-based nanomaterials with enhanced HER activities [36,94]. Overall, the hybrid structure of MOFs integrates the merits of heteroatom dopants and carbon matrix for designing and fabricating nanostructured Mo x C electrocatalysts. Biomass materials, such as soybean [20], glucose [95], and sodium alginate [96], sunflower seed [97], and chitosan [98], have also been considered as the most ideal carbon sources for synthesizing Mo2C-based electrocatalysts due to their ‘‘green’’ properties. Fujita et al. reported biomass-derived composites composed of β-Mo2C phase and γ-Mo2N phase by the controlled solid-state reaction between humble soybeans and molybdenum [20]. The experimental results demonstrated that hybridization of β-Mo2C and γ-Mo2N exhibited high catalytic activity and durability in corrosive acid exceeding 500 h. When coupling with graphene, the composite exhibited enhanced activity and fast charge transfer kinetics. Therefore, the biomass-assisted strategy may pave the pathway for the scaled-up production of Mo x C nanostructures. As seen from the above organic-inorganic strategies for synthesizing various Mo x C nanostructures, the composites could hold the benefits of unique nanostructures, coupling with carbon matrix tightly, and heteroatom doping. Usually, increasing the number of electronically connected active sites via designing ultrafine Mo x C nanocrystals is the foundation to boost HER activity. Due to the inevitable high-temperature process, a large number of Mo x C nanoparticles are inclined to sinter and aggregate together during carbonization process, undoubtedly sacrificing the exposure of highly active species. Therefore, researchers focus on designing and synthesizing various Mo x C composites ranging from zero-dimensional (0D) to three-dimensional (3D) structures to expose rich active sites for the improvement of electrocatalytic HER activity. 3.2 Carbides nanoparticles To overcome the aforementioned sintering and aggregating issues, the design of well-defined Mo x C nanostructures composed of ultrafine nanoparticles, taking the place of traditional nanoparticles, well incorporated into ideal carbon matrix with large surface area and good conductivity is highly desirable [99–101]. Ideal carbon materials, such as carbon nanotubes [102–105], graphene sheets [104,106,107], and N-rich carbon matrix (e.g., melamine and dicyandiamide) [32,108], have been demonstrated as buffering matrix to suppress the aggregation of Mo x C nanocrystals, benefiting the good electrocatalytic activity. Especially, N-rich carbon matrix plays critical role in enhancing the HER performance of Mo x C catalysts, because N dopants could efficiently activate inert carbon into active electrocatalysts [109]. Wang et al. employed dicyandiamide and ammonium molybdate as starting materials to obtain MoO x @g-C3N4 (graphitic carbon nitride) intermediates, and finally synthesized ultrafine Mo2C nanoparticles embeded within carbon matrix (MCNs@carbon), as exhibited in Fig. 5 (a) [108]. High-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images exhibited that ultrafine Mo2C nanoparticles with an average size of less than 3 nm were encapsulated by ~1–3 graphene layers (Fig. 5(b) and (c)). They demonstrated that the ultrafine size and high dispersion of the Mo2C nanoparticles were attributed to the confining effect of the g-C3N4 intermediates, therefore, g-C3N4 played critical role in fabricating ultrafine Mo x C electrocatalysts. The optimized Mo2C catalysts exhibited Pt-like activity with a much smaller onset overpotential of approximately −6 mV and Tafel slope of 41 mV dec−1 (Fig. 5(d)). Takanabe et al. also synthesized Mo2C nanocrystals with a size distribution from 3 to 20 nm within carbon matrix by employing mesporous graphitic nitride (mpg-C3N4) with confined pores. Electrochemical results demonstrated the higher activity of Mo2C catalysts at 1323 K, which was mainly ascribed to the small particle size, high surface area and graphitized carbon layer on the surface of catalyst [110]. Huang's group synthesized ultrafine Mo2C nanoparticles anchored into graphene encapsulating N-doped carbon microspheres (Mo2C/G-NCS) by introducing the as-formed graphene and in-situ formed N-doped porous carbon micropsheres [111]. The intimate interaction of Mo7O24 − and -NH3 + derived from the chitosan molecular ensured the well-regulated ultrafine Mo2C-embeded into N-doped carbon. The as-prepared Mo2C/G-NCS yielded at optimized temperature showed an overpotential of only 70 mV to afford 10 mA cm−2 and a low Tafel slope of 39 mV dec−1. Generally, the surface termination is also an important factor to influence the catalytic efficiency of Mo2C NPs. Therefore, Saidi et al. used a thermodynamic method combined with density functional theory (DFT) and a kinetic model of j0 to investigate the HER activity of β-Mo2C NPs via controlling the surface terminations [112]. As exhibited in Fig. 5(e), the exposed percentage of the (011) termination of Mo2C NPs increased from 61.9% to 88.0% as the carbon chemical potential decreased from −6 to −9 eV. DFT calculation presented the volcano curve of β-Mo2C surfaces and nanoparticles, as revealed in Fig. 5f. It can be seen from Fig. 5(f) that the j 0 of the optimized designed Mo2C NPs was ~10−5 A cm−2, very close to that of Pt (111). 3.3 1D molybdenum carbides Electrochemical water splitting is a typical gas-involving electrochemical reaction, so the catalyst with unique shape and size is pursed to modulate the properties of catalysts and enhance the HER activity of functional systems [46,113,114]. Among different nanostructures, 1D nanostructures with high aspect ratio can not only facilitate charge transfer and possess adequate spaces for exposing superficial active sites, but also empower a texture-induced surface to release gas bubbles from the surface of electrode quickly, which is beneficial for ions and electrons diffusion in a gas-involving HER reaction [115–117]. To this end, Tang's group have prepared unique Mo2C, MoC-Mo2C, and Co-doped Mo2C 1D nanowires by pyrolyzing MoO x /amine hybrid nanowires with sub-nanosized periodic structure in an inert atmosphere, which exhibited excellent electrocatalytic activity towards HER [81,83,84]. Triggered by this organic-inorganic strategy, they also selected another organic organizer (N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF)) combined with MoO4 2− to synthesize 1D mesoskeletal molybdenum carbide (msk-MoC x ) nanorods, in which the periodic inserted DMF served as agent for forming skeleton structure of MoO x NPs and the pre-mixed β-cyclodextrin (β-CD) acted as carbon resource for converting MoO x NPs into MoC x phase [118]. Benefiting from the unique 1D and mesoskeletal structures, the as-prepared msk-MoC x decreased the diffusion resistance of reactants/products and displayed excellent activity for HER in both acidic and alkaline media. Wang et al. synthesized porous Mo2C nanorods via carbonization of MoO4 2− and aniline under H2/Ar atmosphere, and demonstrated that the samples obtained in 20 vol% H2/Ar exhibited no metallic Mo signal and smooth surface [119]. The Mo2C obtained in 20 vol% H2/Ar exhibited excellent electrocatalytic performance for HER in both acidic (32 mA cm−2, at η = 200 mV) and alkaline solutions (30 mA cm−2, at η = 200 mV) and HER performance can be further enhanced by incorporating Ni in to Mo2C to form complex. Besides, the control over the surface area of 1D nanostructures to largely improve the utilization rate of active species should be also taken into consideration. Lou's group employed an unusual template-assisted method to controllably synthesize Mo-polydopamine nanotubes, which were converted into hierarchical β-Mo2C nanotubes constructed from porous nanosheets at high temperature, as exhibited in Fig. 6 (a) [120]. For the formation of Mo-polydopamine nanotubes, the MoO3 nanorods were utilized as self-degradable template and gradually dissolved to provide additional Mo source for the continuous formation of hierarchical Mo-polydopamine nanosheets. As depicted in Fig. 6(b), the β-Mo2C were composed of well-defined nanotubes and the walls of nanotubes were constructed by many 2D nanosheets. TEM image showed that the β-Mo2C nanotubes with a wall thickness of ~90 nm were observed (Fig. 6(c)). HRTEM image revealed that β-Mo2C nanotubes consisted of numerous ultrafine Mo2C nanocrystallites with the size of less than 3 nm, tightly embedded in carbon layers (Fig. 6(d)). Due to the advantages of hierarchical structures, the resulting β-Mo2C nanotubes exhibited small onset potentials (−82 and −37 mV), low Tafel slopes (62 and 55 mV dec−1), and high stability for HER in acidic and alkaline media (Fig. 6(e)–(g)), respectively. In contrast, Tsiakaras et al. developed a template-free method to synthesize three kinds of N-doped Mo2C (nanobelts, nanorods, and nanoparticles) just by controlling water content and treatment time [121]. The corresponding electrochemical results demonstrated that N-doped Mo2C nanobelts displayed superior HER activity to nanorods and nanoparticles, which only needed a small onset potential of −80 and −52 mV and a low Tafel slope of 51.3 and 49.7 mV dec−1 in acidic and alkaline media, respectively. 3.4 2D molybdenum carbides As we know, graphene, as the best known and most typical 2D material, has attracted intensive attention due to the high specific area, unique electronic structure and properties differing from their bulk counterparts [122]. Analogous to 2D graphene, a new intriguing family of 2D materials such as TMCs and carbonitrides, labeled MXene, have been employed successfully in various electrochemical applications [123–125]. The general formula of MXenes is M n +1X n T x (n = 1–3), where M represents early transition metal (such as Mo, V, and Ti), X represents C and/or N, and T x is surface functional groups (such as O, OH, and F) [126,127]. These MXene structures are obtained from layered ternary carbides by selective extraction [128]. Based on this synthesis strategy, Vojvodic et al. synthesized Mo2CT x by HF etching of its parent ternary carbides (Mo2Ga2C) to remove the Ga atoms, rendering excellent activity and high durability for HER in acid, which was verified by both theoretical and experimental results. In addition, theory demonstrated that the basal plane of Mo2CT x was also active for HER, differing from the layer structured MoS2, in which only the edge sites acted as active sites [129]. Zhang et al. utilized high-throughput first-principles method to demonstrate that the HER performance of MXene could be further improved by the introduction of suitable adatom to tailor the electronic structure [130]. Differing from the above selective extraction method for synthesizing MXene, various template-assisted methods are also applied to prepare highly active 2D Mo x C materials. Fellinger and co-workers demonstrated a general salt-templating method to fabricate vertically aligned carbon nanosheets (CNS) and metal carbide@CNS composites, which integrated the merits of ultrathin walls, high electrical conductivity, small particle size, and excellent structure robustness [131]. The obtained MoC0.654@CNS exhibited higher activity than those of WC@CNS, TaC@CNS, and NbC@CNS samples, which gave smaller corresponding overpotential of 220 mV to drive a current density of 10 mA cm−2. Song et al. synthesized Mo2C nanosheets within N-doped carbon (MCNS/NC) by using a Mo-based inorganic-organic lamellar mesostructure (Mo-LM) as precursor through a facile one-step carbonization method [132]. The uniformly distributed MoO4 2− encompassed by the self-assembled organic ligands guaranteed the formation of ultrathin MoO2 nanosheets interconnected with N-doped carbon and the further annealing promoted the carbonization from the surface to the interior of MoO2 nanosheets. The regulated MCNS/NC exhibited an overpotential of only 19 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and a low Tafel slope of 28.9 mV dec−1 in acidic solution. Chen's group reported the synthesis of ultrathin N-doped Mo2C nanosheets (N-Mo2C NSs) using a two-step method of first using CVD system to synthesize MoO2 NSs as template and then pyrolyzing the mixture of dicyandiamide powders (C2H4N4) and MoO2 NSs to produce ultrathin N-Mo2C NSs [133]. DFT results indicated that the N doping of Mo2C NSs could produce more active sites, including Mo and N atoms on the C plane of Mo2C. Benefiting from the unique 2D structure of N-Mo2C NSs and more active sites, the obtained N-Mo2C NSs possessed excellent HER activity with small onset potential of −48.3 mV and low Tafel slope of 44.5 mV dec−1, and high durability in 0.5 M H2SO4. Moreover, the catalytic activity of 2D structure of Mo2C can be further enhanced by metal doping to modulate the electron density of catalyst. For example, 2D porous Mo2C nanostructures (2D-N,Co-Mo2C) were synthesized by carbonization of Co-based ZIF-67 cladding MoO3 nanosheets hybrids at high temperature, as exhibited in Fig. 7 (a) [134]. The synthesized 2D-N, Co-Mo2C displayed porous nanosheet-like structure consisting of many nanoparticles (Fig. 7(b) and (c)). Fig. 7(d) shows that the Mo2C was existed in hexagonal phase derived from selected area electron diffraction pattern (the inset of Fig. 7(d)) and the Mo2C NPs were coated by ultrathin carbon layers with the thickness of ~2.1 nm. The obtained 2D-N,Co-Mo2C showed a small onset overpotential of 25 mV and low Tafel slope of 40 mV dec−1 in 0.1 M HClO4 (Fig. 7(e)) and the onset overpotential of 36 mV and Tafel slope of 47 mV dec−1 in 0.1 M KOH (Fig. 7(f)), which was superior to those of 1D-N,Co-Mo2C and 2D-N-Mo2C. 3.5 3D porous molybdenum carbides Generally, designing unique structures to create abundant defects and improve the surface area and conductivity are desirable for the excellent electrocatalytic activity [135]. 3D carbon matrices with rich pores have attracted much attention due to their unique structure properties, which is beneficial for the charge transfer and mass transport by providing abundant diffusion channels [136]. Recently, several researches attempted to prepare porous 3D porous Mo x C structures via various template-assisted methods. Yan et al. reported the synthesis of 3D porous Mo2C framework (3DHP-Mo2C) via a template-assisted method [137]. The interconnected 3D porous N-doped carbon framework (PNDCF) as template was firstly synthesized via polymerization of pyridine initiated by metal Na, then decomposed into Na/carbon-based materials, and finally rinsed with water to remove residual Na. The well-defined 3DHP-Mo2C obtained by carbonization of Mo-PNDCF hybrids could facilitate the mass transport of proton to the surface of the interior pore, thus exhibiting higher electrocatalytic activity for HER, even superior to the comparative mesoporous electrocatalysts. Their another work focused on synthesizing 3D ordered porous structures of MoC or Mo2C by using carboxylic polystyrene (COOH-PS) spheres as opal hard template [138]. This 3D periodic structure possessed high surface area, different degrees of porosity, and interconnected porous channels, which endowed the catalysts with high HER activity in a wide pH range. Similarly, Baek et al. also employed a facile hard template (SiO2 spheres) strategy to synthesize macroporous inverse opal-like (IOL) Mo x C involving rich Mo vacancies [139], as shown in Fig. 8 (a). Fig. 8(b) shows that the obtained Mo x C-IOL exhibited an IOL structure with the pore size of ~380 nm. TEM image of Mo x C-IOL displayed the obvious boundaries of Mo2C and SiO2 spheres (Fig. 8(c)). DFT analysis indicated that the Mo vacancies introduced-Mo3+ possessed better intrinsic activity than that of Mo2+. Taking this advantage, the Mo x C-IOL with rich Mo vacancies afforded a small onset potential of 79 mV in acidic and only 0.5 mV in alkaline solution (Fig. 8(d) and (e)). Cao and co-workers constructed hierarchically macro‑meso-microporous Mo2C with a 3D architecture (3DHP-Mo2C) by using accessible NaCl as the template [140]. Benefiting from the abundant hierarchically macro‑meso-microporous structure promoting the charge transfer and mass transport, 3DHP-Mo2C exhibited excellent HER electrocatalytic activity with small overpotentials of 166 and 139 mV at 10 mA cm−2 under 0.5 M H2SO4 and 1.0 M KOH, respectively, and high stability. The above works demonstrate that apparent electrocatalytic activity of Mo x C is apparently impacted by its morphology. Because that synthesizing ultrafine Mo x C nanocrystals derived from organic-inorganic hybrids could create a large number of active sites and designing unique Mo x C catalysts ranging from 1D to 3D nanostructures can not only provide abundant channels for charge transfer and mass transport but also improve the surface area and conductivity. However, limited by the intrinsic activity of Mo x C structures, designing unique Mo x C nanostructures can not meet the high requirements of efficient catalysis, therefore, the electrocatalytic activity can be further facilitated by modulating electronic structures and carbon interface. 4 Modulation of heteroatom doping of molybdenum carbides The HER activity of Mo x C catalyst is intrinsically restricted by the large density of empty d-orbitals resulting in the consequent strong H-binding, which restrict the desorption of Hads to produce H2 [63,141,142]. Therefore, nonmetallic elements with low electronegativity (e.g., N, S, and P) [32,133,143,144] and the late-transition-metal elements (Fe, Co and Ni) modulation are revealed to be a promising method to downshift the density of vacancies for Mo x C compounds, to weaken the Mo-H strength and boost HER activity [84,145–149]. 4.1 Nonmetallic dopants Nonmetallic heteroatom doping (e.g., N, S, and P) involve the substitution of C atoms in Mo x C nanocrystals or carbon matrix, to modulate the electronic structure and surface chemistry of Mo x C composites. Chen et al. presented the exposure and top-view of Mo and C atoms for Mo2C and N substitution of C atoms in Mo2C nanocrystal, as shown in Fig. 9 (a)–(c) [133]. They further calculated the ΔG H* of Mo and C atoms on the top plane (T) or on the bottom plane (B) of Mo2C nanocrystals. By comparing the ΔG H* value of Mo and C in Mo2C with N-Mo2C, it can be concluded that N doping induced the generation of new active sites of the N atoms and Mo-3-T atoms on the top plane, which possessed much low |ΔG H*| values of 0.3 and 0.07 eV, respectively (Fig. 9(d) and (e)). The obtained N-Mo2C catalyst exhibited superior HER performance to Mo2C catalyst. Besides N heteroatom, P-doping is also expected to modulate the electronic configuration of Mo2C effectively due to its lower electrical negativity. To this end, Gao and Tang et al. developed the pyrolysis of ternary MoO x -phytic acid-polyaniline (MoO x -PA-PANI) strategy to synthesize controllable P-doping into Mo2C, in which the hierarchical nanowires were composed of P-Mo2C NPs and conducting carbon, as shown in Fig. 9(f) [144]. As shown in Fig. 9(g), the P-Mo2C@C nanowires with optimized P-doping (P: 2.9 wt%) exhibited a small overpotential of 89 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and striking kinetic metrics in acidic solution. Further DFT calculations showed that the P-doped into Mo2C can increase the electron density around Fermi level due to electron transfer into the Mo-H orbitals and steric hindrance of H atoms by P-doped sites on the surface of Mo2C, implying the weakened Mo-H strength. A ΔG H* approaching 0 eV can be realized with optimal P doping, indicating the favorable HER kinetics (Fig. 9(h)). Previous reported widely accepted that surface oxygen is inert and ineffectual for HER process. Very recently, Gao and Tang et al. demonstrated the two impacts of surface oxidation on the HER performance of molybdenum carbides nanoladders derived from pyrolyzing of MoO x /amine hybrid precursors [150]. Surface oxygen can downshift of d-band center in Mo and introduce steric hindrance, and the ΔG H* approaching to 0 eV can be realized with moderate surface oxygen-incorporation. Furthermore, not only restricted by unary-heteroatom doping, a multiple-heteroatoms doping approach could also be applied to synergistically modulate the electronic structure of Mo2C electrocatalyst [143,151]. Yan's group investigated the effect of N and S dual dopants on the HER performance of Mo2C nanosheets. The electrochemical measurements demonstrated that N, S dual-doped Mo2C (NS-doped Mo2C) nanosheet exhibited superior HER activity to N-doped Mo2C, S-doped Mo2C, and pristine Mo2C [143]. They ascribed the superior HER performance of NS-doped Mo2C to the synergistic effect (σ-donation/π-back donation) derived from N and S dopants, which was proposed to lead to the increased adsorption efficiency and the weak HO bond, promoting the generation of H2. Benefiting from this advantage, NS-doped Mo2C nanosheets exhibited a lower onset potential of 46 mV than those of S-doped Mo2C (−144 mV) and N-doped Mo2C (−186 mV), indicating the favorable HER kinetics for HER. Analogously, N, P co-doped Mo x C nanofibers with excellent HER activity in both 0.5 M H2SO4 and 1.0 M KOH were synthesized by Chen and co-authors [151]. 4.2 Metallic dopants Besides the nonmetallic doping to weaken the Mo-H strength, the VIII group transition metals dopants (Fe, Co, and Ni), which possess more electrons than Mo atom, are also employed to increase the electron density around Fermi level, thus weakening the strength of Mo-H. Ni-doped Mo2C nanowires grown directly on Ni foam (NiMo2C/NF) were synthesized via a hydrothermal reaction and following carbonization process [152]. Electrochemical results demonstrated that the NiMo2C/NF was highly active towards HER in 6 M NaOH and possessed smaller onset potential of 21 mV than that of Mo2C/NF (87 mV). DFT calculations indicated that Ni incorporated into the Mo2C can weaken the bind adsorbates (Hads) and realize the charge redistribution on the catalyst, thus facilitating the desorptions of Hads and H2 formation. Cobalt-doped into Mo2C nanowires could also effectively optimize the electron structures around Fermi level, realizing the intrinsically improved HER activity in both acidic and basic media [84]. Ai and co-workers also demonstrated the crucial effect of Co on molybdenum carbide-based electrocatalysts, in which the N-doped carbon encapsulating cobalt and molybdenum carbide nanoparticles (Co x Mo y @NC) were synthesized via a facile one-step carbonization process [147]. Benefiting from the high conductivity and the synergistic effect between Mo x C and Co, the resulting Co x Mo y @NC served as highly active bifunctional catalysts for water splitting. Ticianelli et al. systematically investigated the effect of transition metals (TMs) (Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu) on the reactivity of modified Mo2C (TM-Mo2C) for HER in acidic media [146]. All TM-Mo2C catalysts obtained by a temperature programmed reduction method exhibited high activity with onset potentials lower than −0.06 V, but the HER activity decreased in the order of α-Mo2C > Fe-Mo2C > Co-Mo2C > Ni-Mo2C > Cu-Mo2C. In situ near-edge X-ray adsorption results demonstrated that the electronic effect can modify the d-electron structure of α-Mo2C. Although TM-Mo2C exhibited inferior activity to α-Mo2C, TM-Mo2C was more stable than α-Mo2C in acidic solution. In recent work, Li and co-workers employed Anderson-type polyoxometalates (POMs) (NH4)n[TMMo6O24H6]•5H2O (TM = Ni2+, Co2+, Fe3+, and Cr3+) as precursors to synthesize Ni-, Co-, Fe-, and Cr-doped Mo2C by a high temperature carbonization process, as shown in Fig. 10 (a) [149]. XRD patterns of these catalysts showed analogical structure to Mo2C@C, indicating that no new phase appeared after transition metal doping (Fig. 10(b)). The HER electrocatalytic activity of these catalysts decreased in the following order: Ni-Mo2C > Co-Mo2C > Fe-Mo2C > Cr-Mo2C. The Ni-Mo2C@C exhibited the best HER activity, which only required an overpotential of 72 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and the smaller Tafel slope of 65.8 mV dec−1 (Fig. 10(c)). DFT calculations demonstrated that TM dopants have a significant effect on the ΔG H* of Mo2C, thus influencing the catalytic activity of Mo2C (Fig. 10(d)). Taken together, both the experiment results and DFT calculations demonstrated that nonmetallic element (e.g., N, S, and P) and the late-transition-metal elements (Fe, Co and Ni) doping is feasible strategy to downshift the density of d-vacancies in Mo x C, realizing the feasible modulation on H-binding. It is worth to note that the controlled heteroatom doping is needed to accomplish the modulation of d-orbitals of Mo x C, otherwise, the occurance of new phases such as Mo-heteroatom or heteroatom derived from excessive dopants may affect the HER via the other reaction mechanism. In the following text, we focus on the introduction of the heterostructures of Mo x C composites. 5 Modulation of heterointerfaces of molybdenum carbides For the construction of effective Mo x C-based materials for HER, modulation of chemical composition is a paramount strategy. Distinct from the heteroatom-doping leading to the variation of density of d-orbital vacancies of Mo x C, designing heterointerfaces forming additional phase can also realize the intrinsic enhanced activity of Mo x C-based materials. It is believed that the synergistic effect between two components can modulate the electronic configuration of the composite materials to realize the promoted activity and stability [153]. Generally, modulation of metal components and nonmetal components are two feasible strategies to fabricate effective Mo x C-based catalysts. As expected, a series of Mo x C heterostructures were synthesized, such as Mo2C-Mo(C) [83,154], Mo2C-WC [27,155], Mo2C-Fe3C [156], Mo2C-Mo2S [30,157–161], Mo2C-MoP [162,163], and Mo2C-Mo2N [107,164], to accomplish the intrinsic enhanced HER activity. 5.1 Modulation of metal components Gao and Tang et al. reported the MoC-Mo2C heteronanowires (HNWs) fabricated from MoOx-amine nanowires (NWs) via facile controlled carbonization, as exhibited in Fig. 11 (a) [83]. The XPS results indicated the different Mo3+/Mo2+ ratio (n 3+/2+) on different heteronanowires (Fig. 11(b)) and the variation of Mo3+/Mo2+ were related to the different electron density around Mo3+ and Mo2+. As shown in Fig. 11(c), compared with Mo2C (n 3+/2+ = 0.4), a higher n 3+/2+ of 3.0 (MoC-Mo2C-31.4) showed improved activity, indicating that the rich Mo3+ with fewer electrons promoted HER. Compared with the excellent activity of MoC-Mo2C-31.4, the inferior activity of MoC-Mo2C-68.1 and MoC suggested that weak H-binding involving less electron donated by Mo (Fig. 11(d)). Another work focused on designing large-size atomically thin heteronanosheets (HNS) of Mo/Mo2C heterointerfaces via the salt-templaed process [154]. Theoretical simulation indicated that the double phase interface composed of β-Mo2C and metallic Mo can bring about a more thermo-neutral ΔG H* because the metallic Mo with enriched electrons functioned as electron donor, which would increase the electron density around Fermi level in β-Mo2C. The obtained Mo/Mo2C heterointerfaces obtained at 750 °C demonstrated outstanding HER performance with an overpotential of only 89 and 79 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in acidic and alkaline solutions. The well-defined nanosized Mo2C nanoparticles integrated onto WC structure (nw-W4MoC) was synthesized via a pseudomorphic transformation of molybdenum tungsten oxide [27]. The bimetallic carbides after activation demonstrated outstanding HER performance with high exchange current density of 0.029 mA cm−2, small overpotential of 184 mV to drive a current density of 80 mA cm−2. Liu et al. demonstrated that regulation of additive tungsten amount was a feasible approach to realize the crystal transformation from α-Mo2C → β-Mo2C [155]. Benefiting from the optimal Mo-C bond lengths, Mo x C prepared with an appropriate tungsten amount exhibited the enhanced electrocatalytic activity and stability than pure α-phase and β-phase Mo2C for HER, and required a small overpotential of 148 and 93 mV to drive a current density of 20 mA cm−2 in acidic and alkaline meidia, respectively. Besides metallic W element, metallic Fe element was also introduced to design Fe3C-Mo2C/nitrogen-doped carbon (Fe3C-Mo2C/NC) hetero-nanofibers (HNFs) via an electrospinning followed by a pyrolysis strategy [156]. Due to the strong H-binding on Mo2C and the relative weak one on Fe3C, the Fe3C-Mo2C/NC heterointerfaces demonstrated the promoted HER kinetics and intrinsic activity, which afforded a smaller overpotential of 116 mV to drive 10 mA cm−2. It was worth to note that the electrospinning strategy could be easily applied to fabricate other Mo2C-based heterointerfaces such as Co2C-Mo2C/NC and W2C-Mo2C/NC, which can synergistically boost the HER activity. 5.2 Modulation of nonmetal components Besides the modulation of metal composition, modulation of nonmetal composition (S, P, and N) is also an alternative strategy to synergistically enhance the electrocatalytic HER activity. A hybrid nanostructure composed of vertically aligned MoS2/Mo2C nanosheets on conductive carbon paper were synthesized by hydrothermal to form vertically aligned MoS2 nanosheets and following carbonization process in the flowing of Ar/H2/CH4 to form MoS2/Mo2C hybrids, as shown in Fig. 12 (a) [30]. The MoS2/Mo2C nanosheets obtained in a carbonization time for 25 min showed a layered structure with interplanar distance of 0.64 nm, corresponding to the (002) plane of MoS2 (Fig. 12(b)). And the clear lattice fringes with d spacing of 0.225 and 0.236 nm can be indexed to (211) and (020) facets of orthorhombic Mo2C (Fig. 12(c)), respectively. DFT calculations indicated that S edge of MoS2 was easily for carbonization and then formed a mixed Mo-S-C phase, as illustrated in Fig. 12(d). Fig. 12(e) exhibited the calculated differential Gibbs energy (ΔG diff) as a function of H:Mo ratio of carburized S edge. It can be seen that the H coverage cases of 11 and 12 H atoms for Mo-S-C had the ΔG diff of ~0 eV, implying that certain Mo-S-C motifs were suitable HER catalyst in the high H coverage limit. As expected, the MoS2/Mo2C hybrid exhibited remarkable HER activity with a small overpotential (η 10 = 63 mV) and a low Tafel slope of 48 mV dec−1. The Mo2C/MoS2 hybrid synthesized from chemical conversion of MoS2 by thermal annealing under CH4 and H2 with low contact resistance and low Schottky barrier height were also demonstrated by Lee's group [160]. Another strategy adopted to synthesize Mo2C/MoS x hybrids were to grow MoS x on Mo2C structures. Our group synthesized sandwich-structured Mo2C@NC@MoS x porous nanospheres through covering ultrathin MoS x on MoO2−Mo2C@NC nanospheres (Fig. 13 (a)) [159]. (HR)TEM images of Mo2C@NC@MoS x showed that the thickness of shell exceeding 2 nm covering on the surface of MoO2−Mo2C@NC and the obvious lattice fringe with the interplanar distance of ~0.62 nm demonstrated that ultrathin MoS x were coated on the MoO2−Mo2C@NC surface (Fig. 13(b) and (c)). Benefiting from the synergistic effect between Mo2C and MoS x , the as-obtained Mo2C@NC@MoS x nanospheres exhibited excellent HER performance in acidic media (Fig. 13(d)). And Zhu et al. synthesized ultrathin MoS2 nanosheets on Mo2C-embedded N-doped carbon nanotubes via in situ solid and following hydrothermal reactions, which exhibited excellent HER activity in 0.5 M H2SO4 [157]. Wang et al. fabricated the sulfur decoration of Mo2C with optimized Mo/S molar ratio also served as active and stable electrocatalyst for HER in 0.5 M H2SO4 [158]. Molybdenum carbide and phosphide hybrids (N@MoPC x ) have been synthesized by carbonization of organoimido-derivatized heteropolyoxometalate (Mo4 CNP) precursor [162]. The unique molecular Mo4 CNP structures can prevent the agglomeration and ensure the homogeneous carbonization and phosphorization on the atomic scale, thus exhibiting remarkable activity and stability for HER with a small onset overpotential of 32 mV and Tafel slope of 69.4 mV dec−1 in 0.5 M H2SO4. MoP/Mo2C@C composites synthesized from the Mo/P-based polyoxometalate and dicyandiamide mixture also demonstrated small overpotentials of 89, 136, and 75 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in the media of pH = 0, 7, and 14, respectively [163]. As belonging to the same group with the P element, N derived from Mo2N structures are also demonstrated to be efficient species to modulate the ΔG H* of Mo2C. Fu and co-workers fabricated holey reduced graphene oxide coupling with Mo2N-Mo2C heterojunction (Mo2N-Mo2C/HGr) via the immobilization of H3PMo12O40 (PMo12) clusters on graphite oxide and following calcination process in air and NH3 to form Mo2N-Mo2C/HGr [107]. DFT calculations indicated that the N site on the interface of N-Mo-C served as the main active center in enhancing the HER performance of Mo2N-Mo2C, which needed ultrasmall onset potentials of 11 and 18 mV in 0.5 M H2SO4 and 1 M KOH, respectively. Yeo et al. obtained crystalline, phase pure and monodisperse α-Mo2C and γ-Mo2N nanoparticles via the ‘urea glass’ route, which needed a small overpotential of only 176 mV to drive 10 mA cm−2 in 1.0 M KOH [164]. In addition, owing to the easily oxidized Mo x C, the surface Mo oxides are inevitably generated when exposed to air. Different from before we think Mo oxides serving as electrochemical inert species, Gao et al. recently reported heterostructured Mo2C-MoO x on carbon cloth (Mo2C-MoO x /CC) requiring a low overpotential of 60 mV to afford 10 mA cm−2 in 1.0 M HClO4, outperforming the Mo2C/CC, demonstrating that MoO x have positive effect on the HER performance [165]. The excellent HER performance of heterostructured Mo2C-MoO x /CC can be ascribed to that Mo (VI) oxides are in-situ reduced to Mo (IV), accomplishing the promoted HER activity in acidic solution. This report inspires us to look at the surface oxygen species on Mo x C in a new light. Overall, these Mo x C heterostructures have essentially improved HER performance compared with pristine Mo x C structures because of the mutual interaction between these components, which may determine the electronic configuration, surface exposure, and even HER mechanism. Thus, developing multicomponent Mo x C heterostructures with a highly active surface play a crucial role in determining the HER performance. 6 Modulation of carbon interfaces of molybdenum carbides While designing unique nanostructures or heterostructures generally improve the electrochemical activity of the Mo x C structures, it is still inadequate in improving the exposure and utilization of surface. As the essential part of Mo x C, employing ideal carbon materials coupling with Mo x C can realize the as-above mentioned requirements and also possess following functionalities: (1) the nanosized Mo x C can be well-dispersed to avoid its agglomeration, (2) the electrical resistance can be reduced and the conductivity can be improved, (3) the mass/charge transfer rate can be accelerated and the as-formed H2 bubbles can be released quickly, (4) the Mo x C coated by stable carbon materials can effectively protect metals from direct contact with strong acid or alkaline electrolytes and prevent them from being oxidized, and (5) the electronic configuration of active sites can be tuned via interfacial interactions of carbon and Mo x C [47]. Carbon-based supports, e.g., carbon nanotubes [102,166,167], carbon xerogel [102], graphenes [111,168], reduced graphene oxide [33,106], carbon cloth [169], etc., which are already formed before generating Mo x C structures (as-formed carbon), are considered as the promising supporting material to disperse Mo x C composites due to their unique structure and outstanding properties, usually leading to improved conductivity, high specific surface area, and electrochemical stability, however, they are also limited by their high cost and poor contact with carbides. The other kind of carbon, which are formed during the process of generating Mo x C structures, are denoted as “in situ-formed carbon”. The “in situ-formed carbon” can serve as reductants to reduce Mo oxides to Mo x C at high temperature, thus ensuring the intimate contact between Mo x C and carbon matrix, but these carbon materials are usually uncontrollable and with poor graphitization. In this part, we introduce the effect of these two kinds of carbon on the Mo x C structures. 6.1 Supporting molybdenum carbides by as-formed carbon 1D carbon nanotubes (CNTs) are known to be either their metallic or semiconducting relying on the chirality and diameter [170], so they are ideal carbon materials to load Mo x C nanoparticles. Adzic et al. reported the synthesis of Mo2C anchored on CNTs (Mo2C/CNT) by a facile carbonization process [103]. The TEM image of Mo2C/CNT showed that Mo2C nanoparticles with the size ranging from 7 to 15 nm were well-distributed on the CNTs without aggregation (Fig. 14 (a)). X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) indicated the electron transfer from loading Mo2C to carbon on the Mo2C/CNT (Fig. 14(b)), which would weaken the H-binding, and in turn favored the Tafel or Heyrovsky step, thus leading to the enhanced HER activity. The Mo2C/CNT showed the better HER activity in 0.1 M HClO4 than that of bulk Mo2C, which only required an overpotential of 152 mV to drive 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 14(c)). Enhanced HER activity by loading Mo2C nanoparticles on CNTs were also realized by Figueiredo's group, in which the Mo2C/CNT exhibited low Tafel slope and good stability in acid (0.1 M HClO4) and basic (8 M KOH) media [102]. Moreover, Mo2C/CNT hybrids obtained via spray drying and following carbonization process (Mo2C/CNT-SC) also delivered superior HER performance with an extremely small onset overpotential of ~20 mV and a small Tafel slop of 53.6 mV dec−1 [166]. 2D graphene oxide (GO), a one-atom-thick sheet with sp 2-bonded carbon atoms in a hexagonal crystal lattice, has attracted much interest for HER applications [171]. As the ultrathin material, graphene possesses the advantages of high specific surface area, excellent mechanical strength, good electrical conductivity, and thermal stability, thereby it can serve as idea carbon matrix to couple with active Mo x C nanoparticles. Generally, the graphene oxide (GO) is converted to reduced graphene oxide (RGO) during the preparation of Mo x C because the high thermal process is unavoidable. Tao et al. synthesized ultrafine MoC (~2.5 nm) and Mo2C (~5.0 nm) nanoparticles on graphene via a simple in situ method [106]. Benefiting from a great deal of active sites due to the ultrafine sizes, fast electron transfer rate derived from graphene, porous microstructure, and clean surfaces of the MoC and Mo2C nanoparticles, the obtained electrocatalysts exhibited high activity for HER in acidic media. To avoid the introduction of H2 or CH4 for synthesizing nanostructured Mo x C, the second carbon sources are usually adopted to the reaction system. Huang et al. synthesized ultrafine Mo2C nanoparticles embeded into graphene wrapping N-doped porous carbon microspheres (Mo2C/G-NCS) using chitosan and ammonium molybdate (AM) as carbon and Mo source, respectively, as illustrated in Fig. 14(d) [111]. The (HR)TEM image revealed that ultrafine Mo2C nanoparticles with average size of ~4 nm were embedded into carbon matrix (Fig. 14(e)). The Mo2C/G-NCS 750 catalyst under the optimized condition displayed excellent HER performance in both acidic (η10 = 70 mV) (Fig. 14(f)) and alkaline (η10 = 66 mV) solutions (Fig. 14(g)). Analogously, the second carbon materials, such as polyaniline [172], polypyrrole [33,173], glucose [95], urea [104], etc., were also employed to serve as carbon source to ensure the complete carbonization in Mo x C/RGO hybrids. 3D carbon cloth (CC) is also an appealing material to load Mo x C structures due to its rich channels for mass diffusion, high conductivity, and excellent acid resistance [174]. Zou et al. fabricated well-dispersed Mo2C micro-islands on flexible CC, in which the presence of cetyltrimethyl ammonium bromide was critical because it can not only immobilize molybdate ions on CC but also provide carbon for the formation of Mo2C [169]. The Mo2C/CC exhibited a low overpotential of 140 mV to afford 10 mA cm−2 and kept stable in acid with a Faraday efficiency of ~100%. A 3D hierarchical porous Mo2C framework (3DHP-Mo2C) with large surface area of 302 m2 g−1 were synthesized by employing porous nitrogen-doped carbon framework as precursors, which exhibited much lower HER overpotential in a wide pH range [137]. 6.2 Supporting molybdenum carbides by in situ-formed carbon Contrary to as-formed carbon, the organic polymer (e.g., poly-aniline, -pyrrole, -dopamine) [28,81,120,175] and environmental friendly biomass (e.g., soybean, sodium alginate, bacterial cellulose, chitosan, glucose) [20,35,95,96,111,176] with rich C atoms can not only serve as carbon sources but also act as reductants to promote the construction of Mo x C electrocatalysts simultaneously, which will avoid the disadvantages of interface reactions in preparation of Mo x C, such as the complex TPRe process. In addition, a series of organic-inorganic strategies to synthesize Mo x C nanostructures endow these materials various functional properties and regulated subnanometer periodic structures. The widely reported polyaniline has been considered as ideal candidates to fabricate unique Mo2C structures due to the strong electrostatic interactions between aniline and molybdate anions, which ensures the subnanometer contact for the formation of molybdenum oxides and amine molecules, thus facilitating the achievement of Mo2C nanostructures with remarkable properties and modulated morphology [69,82]. Inspired by researches of Tang and Gao et al., the controlled synthesis of organic-inorganic hybrids, followed by carbonization, has been considered as an effective strategy to design polymer-derived Mo x C nanostructures. The Mo2C-anchored N-doped porous carbon nanosheets (Mo2C@2D-NPC) was fabricated by synthesizing Mo4O13 2−-anchored PANI nanosheet (Mo@2D-PANI) firstly through in situ polymerization at the toluene/water interface and then pyrolyzed under hydrogen/argon atmosphere at high temperature [177]. The obtained Mo2C@2D-NPC exhibited ultralow overpotential of ~45 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 in alkaline media. Porous 1D Mo2C based catalysts with tubular structures were synthesized by in situ solid reactions using MoO3-PANI nanorods and then carbonized to 1D Mo2C nanostructures, which exhibited high activity and long-term stability in a wide pH range [178,179]. Polypyrrole (PPy), as a N-containing carbon source, can also serve as ideal carbon matrix and reductants to fabricate Mo2C nanostructures. In addition, H3PMo12O40•nH2O (PMo12), as a typical Keggin type heteropolyanions of polyoxometalates (POMs), has a great advantage of strong redox ability to initiate the polymerization of organic pyrrole (Py) monomer. Hu et al. synthesized well-defined pomegranate-like N, P-doped Mo2C@C nanospheres by employing PMo12 to initiate the polymerization of PPy, which exhibited excellent HER activity in 1 M KOH [28]. Lan and co-workers synthesized Co-Mo-based carbide (Co6Mo6C2) coated by N-doped carbon and loaded on N-doped RGO film (Co6Mo6C2/NCRGO) by directly carbonizing the Co-doped POMs/PPy/GO precursors. The introduction of Py monometer into PMo12/GO solution ensured the spherical-shaped PPy formed on the surface of GO due to the redox ability of PMo12, and PPy encased PMo12 particles during in situ polymerization process [173]. The Co6Mo6C2/NCRGO, as the OER electrocatalyst, showed an ultrasmall overpotential of 260 mV at 10 mA cm−2. Dopamine, composed of catechol and amino functional groups, has accumulated great interests as ideal support to fabricate functional Mo x C structures due to their self-polymerization in alkaline solution and strong complexation ability with MoO4 2− [180–182]. Novel hierarchical β-Mo2C organized by porous nanosheets were fabricated via a template-assisted method by using MoO3 nanorods as both template and additional Mo source accompanied by the polymerization of dopamine in situ and then followed by carburizing under inert atmosphere, which exhibited excellent electrocatalytic HER performance in both acidic and alkaline media [120]. Ultrasmall Mo2C nanoparticles uniformly dispersed on 3D N-doped carbon microflowers (Mo2C/NCF) were synthesized by using dopamine as precursor. The hierarchical micro- and nanostructure of the Mo2C/NCF preserved their large surface areas and electrochemical accessibility, largely avoided the particle sintering and entangle or aggregate of carbon support, just as exhibited in Fig. 15 (a) [175]. As shown in Fig. 15(b) and (c), Mo2C/NCF exhibited well-dispersed 3D microflower-like morphology and every microflower were composed of numerous loosely stacked nanoflakes with an average thickness of ~10 nm. The strong interaction between MoO4 2− and catechol groups of dopamine limited the excessive growth of polymer and the high-surface support prevented Mo2C nanoparticle from extensive aggregation. By virtue of these advantages, the Mo2C/NCF exhibited excellent HER activity with small onset overpotentials of 40 mV and 38 mV in 0.5 M H2SO4 and 1 M KOH, respectively (Fig. 15(d) and (e)). In addition, metallic Ni-doped Mo2C microflowers (Ni-Mo2C/C MF) were also synthesized by employing dopamine as carbon source [183]. Biomass, such as soybean, sodium alginate, bacterial cellulose, chitosan, and glucose, is considered as low-cost and ‘‘green’’ chemical agents to prepare Mo2C-based nanocatalysts. Chen et al. combined Mo2N with Mo2C nanocomposites by using soybean as the carbon and nitrogen source and MoO4 2− as the molybdenum source via the solid-state reaction [20]. The hybridization of Mo2C and Mo2N leaded to the high catalytic activity and durability. Cui et al. synthesized Mo2C nanoparticles on graphitic carbon sheets (Mo2C/GCSs) by employing sodium alginate as the carbon source [96], which exhibited high activity with an onsetpotential of 120 mV in acidic media. Yu et al. reported the synthesis of ultrafine Mo2C nanoparticles embedded within 3D N-doped carbon nanofiber (Mo2C@NCNFs) via solid-state reaction of MoO4 2− and bacterial cellulose (BC) as carbon source [35]. The procedures for preparing Mo2C@NCNF aerogels experienced a freeze-drying and following pyrolyzing process (Fig. 16 (a)). Fig. 16(b) and (c) shows that the as-prepared Mo2C@NCNF aerogel inherited the intrinsic 3D network microstructure of BC with 10–20 nm nanofibers. This leaded to abundant interconnected macropores and excellent conductivity. The HRTEM image showed the existence of hexagonal Mo2C embedded within NCNFs (Fig. 16(d)). Electrochemical measurements demonstrated that Mo2C@NCNF catalysts exhibited superior HER activity to their counterparts (Fig. 16(e)), indicating the positive effect of the ultrafine Mo2C nanoparticles and the coupling effect between Mo2C and NCNFs, which was reflected from the smallest |ΔG H*| value of Mo2C@NCNF (Fig. 16(f)). Therefore, the biomass-assisted strategy is a promising methodology for low-cost, environmental friendly, and scaled-up fabrication of noble metal-free Mo x C catalysts. 6.3 Synergistic effect of molybdenum carbides and carbon interfaces Based on the above analysis, we can conclude that the Mo x C structures intimately combined with carbon species on the interfaces can synergistically enhance the electrochemical activity of hybrids. One theory leading to the favorable electrocatalytic activity of TMC/carbon composites is that the electron transfer from Mo2C to nonmetal carbon weaken the strong H-binding, and the more positively charged Mo atoms imply the decreased d-band center, thus leading to the enhanced HER activity [103]. Lee et al. investigated electronic effect between series molybdenum compounds (Mo2C, Mo2N, and MoS2) and carbon nanotube-graphene hybrid support by XANES spectra [104]. They demonstrated that the half-step energy increased when the Mo compounds were loaded on nanotube-graphene support, indicating the charge transfer from metal to support, thus leading to the lowered d-band center. In addition, the DFT calculations and experimental data of the as-obtained Mo2C/XC, Mo2C/CNT [103], and Mo2C-GNR [184] also demonstrated the similar mechanism that covalent bonding between the Mo2C and carbon could downshift the d-band center of Mo. When the in situ-formed carbon derived from organic polymer and biomass are employed to fabricate Mo x C structures, the formed ultrathin carbon layers usually encapsulate the Mo x C nanoparticles, therefore, the other theory leading to the favorable electrocatalytic activity of TMC/carbon composites is that Mo2C and heteroatoms doping can activate the ultrathin pristine carbon layers, thus resulting in the optimized ΔG H*. Liu et al. systemically investigated the effect of dopants and the Mo2C/nanocarbon interface on the HER catalytic activity of Mo2C nanoparticles embedded in nitrogen-rich carbon (Mo2C@NC) via DFT calculations [32]. They demonstrated that the C atoms adjacent to the N dopants were the most active species in Mo2C@NC, and a complex electron-transfer process occurred among Mo2C, C, and N in Mo2C@NC, so the neighboring C atoms not only served as electron acceptors but also acted as electron donors. The synergy between Mo2C and N dopants endowed the Mo2C@NC unprecedented catalytic activity in a wide pH range. The similar reaction mechanism was also observed on Mo2C@2D-NPCs [177] and Mo2C@NCNF catalysts [36]. In some circumstance, the as-formed carbon combined with in situ-formed carbon are employed to fabricate functional Mo x C structures, so the interfaces effect of Mo x C and heteroatom-doped carbon are worthy of investigation. To this end, Lan et al. designed and fabricated Mo2C encapsulated by N, P-codoped carbon shells and RGO (Mo2C@NPC/NPRGO) with a 2D structures by employing PMo12(H3PMo12O40)-PPy/RGO as the precursor, as shown in Fig. 17 (a) and (b) [33]. As evident in Fig. 17(c) and (d), the Mo2C@NPC/NPRGO exhibited 2D nanosheets morphology with a large density of nanosized Mo2C NPs (2–5 nm) embedded in the carbon shells. The Mo2C@NPC/NPRGO exhibited the unexpected Pt/C-like activity with the onset overpotential of 0 mV (Fig. 17(e)). DFT calculations indicated that the active sites for the HER were mainly composed of pyridinic N atoms and C atoms of graphene, and the synergistic effect between Mo2C and C-pyridinic N, making the Mo2C@C-pyridinic N have a favorable ΔG H* (−0.22 eV) (Fig. 17(f)). Based on the above analysis, both as-formed and in situ-formed carbon nanostructures play critical role in enhancing the electrochemical activity of Mo x C structures by forming the intimate Mo x C/carbon interfaces, in which the electronic configuration of active species can be modulated to produce optimized ΔG H*. In addition, the carbon matrix in intimate contact with Mo x C structures can boost mass transport and charge transfer on well-dispersed active sites and the formed carbon layer can prevent active sites from corrosion in harsh conditions. 7 Summary and future perspectives In summary, Mo x C-based composites have long been strongly considered as promising materials for hydrogen evolution reaction. In this review, we introduce the microstructure evolution of the design and construction of Mo x C-based composites for high HER performance. For the development of high performance Mo x C composites, the modulation principles on Mo x C-based electrocatalysts are also established including: (1) modulation of morphology to improve the apparent activity of catalyst, (2) modulation of electronic structures of active sites by heteroatom doping and designing heterointerface to boost intrinsic HER kinetics, (3) modulation of electrode interface via hybridization of Mo x C structures with carbon materials to ensure the electron transfer and boost the activity. With facile modulation of hybrid precursors and calcination process, the morphology, crystalline structure, and electronic configuration of carbides can be tailored to realize the enhanced HER performance. Table 1 shows the electrochemical HER performance of different nanostructured Mo x C electrocatalysts in different electrolyte, which were constructed based on the above mentioned modulation strategies. Although significant progress in Mo x C composites for efficient HER have been achieved, their activity are still inferior to the noble metal Pt-based catalysts, therefore, there are still great challenges and questions that need to be emphasized and tackled in the future. Firstly, it can be seen from Table 1 that the many Mo x C electrocatalysts exhibit remarkable HER performance in a wide pH range. Due to the fact that rare catalysts perform well for OER in acidic solution and recently reported Ni-based electrocatalysts exceeds the benchmark catalysts (Ru and Ir) in alkaline media for OER, Mo x C structures are potential for large scale hydrogen production in alkaline meidia to replace Pt toward the efficient water splitting. Since Pt perform well in acidic electrolytes for HER, its catalytic activity is about 2 orders of magnitude lower in alkaline media. While Mo x C structures perform well in a wide pH range, especially in alkaline media. Therefore, development of cost-effective methods for large-scale production of Mo x C-based catalysts as the cathode, combined with noble-metal-free Ni-based electrocatalysts as the anode is a feasible strategy for building up sustainable and efficient electrolysis system. Generally, previous researches employ ΔG H* to predict how the crystal structure, heteroatoms doping, electronic state and the coupled materials affect the HER performance of catalysts [185,186]. As argued by Nørskov et al. [142], ΔG H* can serve as a thermodynamic descriptor to predict HER activities in acidic solution. However, examining the adsorption and dissociation of a H2O on the catalyst surface should also be taken into consideration to provide grateful insights into the qualitative trend of alkaline HER activity [187,188]. Accordingly, ideal Mo x C composites should not only bind water sufficiently to accelerate electron-transfer process but also facilitate the following water dissociation, which are usually ignored in the DFT calculations for alkaline HER [189]. Therefore, more convincing evidence should be provided to speculate the highly active sites for HER. In situ characterization techniques of electrode reaction (e.g. In situ Raman, XANES, and EXAFS) have played more important role in probing the molecular-level interfacial structure of catalysts, which can predict the active sites for HER based on the model [190–192]. Therefore, the in-depth catalytic mechanism in alkaline media calls for the combination of DFT calculations and in situ characterization techniques (e.g. In situ Raman, XANES, and EXAFS) to interpret the possible structure-activity relationship, thus providing guidelines to design and optimize Mo x C composites with high HER activity. Secondly, as proved by XPS results, surface oxidation of Mo x C composites usually occurs due to the unavoidable high temperature process, resulting in the formation of Mo oxides in almost all the Mo x C composites. Although it has been demonstrated that Mo oxides may have positive effect on the HER performance of Mo x C composites, controlling the degree of oxidation is necessary to meet the high requirement of water splitting. Due to the fact that gas-involving HER electrocatalysis is surface reaction involving the mass diffusion and interfacial charge at active centers, excessive surface Mo oxides would affect the HER performance [193–195]. Jaramillo et al. have reported that sulfur anions into phosphides can greatly suppresses the oxidation of Mo x C surface [193–196]. Inspired by this work, anions modulation may provide a prospective on improving the stability of Mo x C in ambient air, and also controlling the degree of oxidation. Finally, in terms of practical application, the stability/durability of electrocatalysts needs more attention to realize large-scale hydrogen generation from water electrolysis. Metal nanoparticles coated by ultrathin carbon layers have been demonstrated as promising nanostructures to maintain the high stability compared with pristine metal nanoparticles, probably due to the fact that ultrathin carbon shells can protect active nanoparticles from corrosion in harsh acidic or alkaline media [197–199]. For Mo x C composites, the employed as-formed or in situ-formed carbon can not only be responsible for forming Mo x C but also generate the graphitic carbon layers coating on the Mo x C surface. However, the carbon layers used for these catalysts are usually too thick and composed of multilayer graphitic carbon, which would severely reduce the catalytic activity for HER. Only when the outer shell are composed of no more than three to four carbon layers, the electronic configuration of the outermost carbon layer can be modulated via the electron transfer from the encapsulated metal sites [200,201]. To this end, synthesizing carbon-encapsulated Mo x C catalysts with controlled graphene layers, especially with less than three layers of graphene carbon play critical role in preventing the corrosion of Mo x C nanoparticles and simultaneously promoting the surface reaction due to the easy electron penetration from the encapsulated Mo x C. Therefore, the rational design and control over the synthesis process of Mo x C composites may overcome these bottlenecks to realize the large-scale hydrogen production.
