Alloys Compd.712 (2017) 103–110. Jing-Qi Chi received B.S. degree from China University of Petroleum (East China). She is pursuing her Ph.D. degree under the supervision of Professor Chen-Guang Liu and Professor Bin Dong in the State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum (East China). Her research interests focus on the design and synthesis of transition metal-based unqiue nanostructure for electrochemical and photoelectrochemical water splitting. Min Yang received B.S. degree from Yantai University. She is pursuing her master degree under the supervision of Professor Yong-Ming Chai and Professor Bin Dong in the State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum (East China). Her research interests focus on the Fe-based nanostructure for electrocatalysis for water splitting. Prof. Yong-Ming Chai received his Ph.D. degree from China University of Petroleum (East China) in 2008. Now he is a professor in State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, College of Chemical Engineering, China University of Petroleum (East China). He was doing research as a visiting scholar in Marquette University from 2015.03 to 2016.03. His-research interests are catalyst of hydrodesulfurization process of heavy oil and transition metal-based electrocatalysts. Prof. Zhi Yang received his B.S. and Ph.D. degree from Lanzhou University in 1999 and 2005, respectively. Now he is a professor in Department of Micro/Nano Electronics, School of Electronic Information and Electrical Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, P. R. China. His-research interests mainly focus on the nanomaterials and devices. Prof. Lei Wang received his Ph.D degree in chemistry from the Jilin University in 2006 under the supervision of Prof. Shouhua Feng. Afterward, he joined the Qingdao University of Science and Technology. From 2008 to 2010, he worked as a postdoctoral fellow in the State Key Laboratory of Crystal Materials, Shandong University. Since 2014, he has been a professor of chemistry at Qingdao University of Science and Technology. In recent years, he has devoted himself to the design and synthesis of porous MOFs materials and functional inorganic materials, as well as their applications in gas separation, photocatalysis, lithium-ion battery, etc. Dr. Bin Dong received his B.S. and Ph.D. degree from Lanzhou University in 2002 and 2008, respectively. He was doing research as a visiting scholar in Marquette University from 2014.03 to 2015.03. Now Dr. Dong is an associate professor in College of Science, China University of Petroleum (East China). His-research interests mainly focus on the transition metal-based functional materials for energy conversion and storage including electrocatalysis and photoelectrocatalysis for small molecules.

coredata.dc:description: The green production of hydrogen from electrocatalytic water splitting is an important base and promising direction for the future of the large-scale application of hydrogen energy. The key of green hydrogen evolution depends on the development of low-cost and highly active electrocatalysts. Molybdenum carbides (Mo x C), as a typical of earth-abundant transition-metal material, have accumulated great attention due to their low cost, earth abundance, electrical conductivity, similar d-band state to Pt, and regulated morphology/electronic structures. In this paper, recent researches focusing on Mo x C for efficient HER in a wide pH range are summarized from respects of modulation of unique morphology, electronic structure, and electrode interface step by step. Briefly, modulation of morphology influence the apparent activity of catalyst, modulation of electronic structure of active sites by heteroatom doping and designing heterointerface boost intrinsic HER kinetics, and modulation of electrode interface via hybridization of MoxC structures with carbon materials can ensure the fast electron transfer and boost the activity. Besides the above methods discussed, perspective and challenges of designing Mo x C as the substitute of Pt-based electrocatalyst for practical hydrogen generation in a wide pH range are pointed out.
